content.description: This is the long, continuous chimney near the right end of the Flying Fortress.

climbs.name: Thumbs Up
climbs.fa: Dennis Yates and Roger Linfield, April 1985

content.description: Start up the lower crack, via liebacking and jamming.  A friction traverse left (5.10A) leads to the base of the lower crack.  Do a few thin moves (5.10A) and reach easier jamming and the top.
content.location: This route was named for its appearance from a distance.  It's the next route right of New Day Yesterday, connecting two cracks via a face traverse in the middle.

content.description:
This is the left of 2 similar flares in the middle of the south face.  Both have sustained hand cracks.

Rap from slings around a boulder above No Self Control (left of the flares). I think one 60m will reach.
A poorly protected but excellent hard face/crack line that was originally done on top rope by Tony Yaniro.
content.protection: Powerful face moves with only the occasional dicey protection.  Can you say Serious?

climbs.name: No Self Confidence
climbs.fa: Dennis Yates and Roger Linfield, Dec. 1983

content.description: This is the right of 2 similar flares in the middle of the south face.  Both have sustained hand cracks.

climbs.name: New Day Yesterday
climbs.fa: Dennis Yates and Roger Linfield, January 1984

content.description: A moderate chimney leads up to the obvious, large alcove.  Tricky hand jamming (crux) takes you up to a good rest spot, with easier (5.9) hand jamming above.
content.protection: mostly hand and fist size gear
content.location: To the right of the large broken section in the middle of the face, there is a straight-in crack with a flare (Hyperventilation) and then this route.  There is an obvious alcove about two-thirds of the way up, narrowing to a hand crack at the top.

climbs.name: Hyperventilation
climbs.fa: Roger Linfield and Dennis Yates, April 1985

content.description: The crux is near the start: an intermittent thin crack in the back of a shallow, flared chute that may get you breathing hard.  You can get good protection for this section.  Above, weird stemming leads to a strenuous chimney and then an easier chimney.
content.location: There is a large broken area in the middle of the wall.  This climb follows the first continuous crack system to the right of the broken area.

climbs.name: 42N8 One
climbs.fa: Dennis Yates and Roger Linfield, January 1984

content.description: Climb up to the large overhang, jam out and over (crux, really fun) and on to the top.
content.protection: standard rack, with emphasis on hand and fist size gear
content.location: There is a large broken area in the middle of the face.  This is the first major crack system to the left.
